qas.question: What were some of the names given to language during period of foreign control?
What specific historical event caused a group of religious and verbal differences in South Slavic dialect?
Why was Shtokavian the most widespread culture in the western Balkans?
What was historically formed by the Ottoman Empire?

plausible_answers.text: a patchwork of dialectal and religious differences

qas.question: What happened due to expansion of Shtokavian?
Due to population change, what became widespread in Kajkavian?
What dialect went into the area previously occupied by Bosniaks and Croats?
What was the Ottoman Empire often a part of?

context: South Slavic dialects historically formed <b3_0>a continuum<b3_0/>. The turbulent history of the area, particularly due to <a1_0>expansion of the Ottoman Empire<a1_0/>, resulted in <b4_0>a patchwork of dialectal and religious differences<b4_0/>. Due to <a2_0>population migrations<a2_0/>, <b5_0><b6_0>Shtokavian<b6_0/><b5_0/> became the most widespread in the western Balkans, intruding westwards into the area previously occupied by Chakavian and Kajkavian (which further blend into Slovenian in the northwest). Bosniaks, Croats and Serbs differ in religion and were historically often part of <b7_0>different cultural circles<b7_0/>, although a large part of the nations have lived side by side under foreign overlords. During that period, the language was referred to under a variety of names, such as <a0_0>"Slavic", "Illyrian", or according to region, "Bosnian", "Serbian" and "Croatian"<a0_0/>, the latter often in combination with "Slavonian" or "Dalmatian".
